content.question:
For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate. 

<math alttext="H C l O, aqueous, plus H 2 O, liquid, is in equilibrium with H 3 O with a positive 1 charge, aqueous, plus C l O with a negative 1 charge, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HClO</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>⇄</mo></mrow></mrow><msup><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>ClO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>

The reaction between hypochlorous acid and water is represented above.

A. Identify one of the conjugate acid-base pairs in the reaction.

frqParts.text:
For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate. 

<math alttext="H C l O, aqueous, plus H 2 O, liquid, is in equilibrium with H 3 O with a positive 1 charge, aqueous, plus C l O with a negative 1 charge, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HClO</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>⇄</mo></mrow></mrow><msup><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>ClO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>

The reaction between hypochlorous acid and water is represented above.

A. Identify one of the conjugate acid-base pairs in the reaction.

B. Shown in the graph below is the titration curve that results when <math alttext="25.0 milliliters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>25.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="0.200 molar H C l O" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.200</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>HClO</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is titrated with <math alttext="0.200 molar N a O H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.200</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>NaOH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>. Carefully draw a second curve on the graph that would result from the titration of <math alttext="25.0 milliliters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mn>25.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="0.200 molar H C l O 4" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.200</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>HCl</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> with <math alttext="0.200 molar N a O H " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.200</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>NaOH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>.

C. A student proposes creating a buffer by dissolving <math alttext="0.010 mole" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.010</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>mol</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="N a C l O 4, solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NaCl</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> in <math alttext="100. decimal point milliliters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>100.</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="0.100 molar H C l O 4" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.100</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext></mtext><mtext></mtext><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>HCl</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. Explain why the resulting solution would not be a buffer.

skill.text: 1.A: Describe the components of and quantitative information from models and representations that illustrate particulate-level properties only.
